0.body: Taj’s biryani is not too spicy and the rice is beautiful – light, fluffy, delightfully grainy with pieces of cashews and raisins for a Persian touch. The chicken biryani comes with a whole tender thigh flavourful with masala spices.
0.name: Taj Authentic Indian Cuisine

1.body: Serving up authentic North Indian & Lebanese food of excellent and consistent quality.
1.description: Serving up authentic North Indian & Lebanese food of excellent and consistent quality.
1.name: A1 Indian Curry & Falafel Lebanese Cafe

2.body: Masterchef SG season 1 finalist and foodie, Syamsydar Ani comments that "if you’re looking for Indian-style Karipap in the area, Sha Zah’s is (her) top pick. The potato and meat in the Karipap are infused with an aromatic blend of spices, and are enclosed in a pleasantly light and flaky pastry."
2.description: Halal Indian-style Karipap in Geylang area
2.name: Sha Zah Confecitonary

3.body:
Komala Vilas Restaurant has been one of the oldest Indian Vegetarian Restaurants, which started in 1947. It still remains a family run business into its 3rd Generation of owners. We keep it traditional, we keep it fresh, we keep it authentic-  Only for you to enjoy the finest tasting Indian food. 

Komala Vilas is best known for its Dosais and the South Indian Vegetarian Meals. Our chefs are continuously creating new dishes like the Mock Mutton Murtabak, the Fishless Fish curry and the Prawn-less Prawn Sambal. True accompaniments to your Dosai or Rice, or whatever you like! 

Come by to poke the Puffed Bhattura and bite into the chewy dough dunked in Chickpea curry. Perfect for all-day dining at a casual shop house restaurant that conjures nostalgic experiences for many.
3.description: Legacy of Authentic Indian Vegetarian Food
3.name: KOMALA VILAS RESTAURANT

4.body: Indian-Muslim restaurant known for their nasi biryani and murtabak.
4.description: Indian-Muslim restaurant known for their nasi biryani and murtabak.
4.name: Al Tasneem

5.body: Known for being one of the top North Indian restaurants in Singapore, Copper Chimney is the place to be for that authentic taste of North Indian cuisine. Whether it's Tandoori Kebab, Naan or Mutton Roganjosh, it will definitely be a treat for the senses. For an interesting twist, try their popular Hakka noodles and Szechuan Fried Rice, made with only the finest Szechuan peppers from China.
5.description: Known for being one of the top North Indian restaurants in Singapore, Copper Chimney is the place to be for that authentic taste of North Indian cuisine.
5.name: Copper Chimney

6.body: Established in 1924, Ananda Bhavan Restaurant is the oldest Indian vegetarian restaurant in Singapore. Its popular set meals include vegetarian briyani (an Indian spiced rice dish), but the real draw lies in fuss-free items like the boli (sweet lentil flatbread) and pani puri (crispy shells stuffed with tamarind chutney). It prides itself on the fact that no monosodium glutamate (MSG) preservatives or additives are used, keeping the wellness of guests in mind. Main courses from S$9. Ananda Bhavan Restaurant is located in Tekka Centre and other locations islandwide.
6.description: The oldest Indian vegetarian restaurant in Singapore serves up fuss-free dishes and popular set meals.
6.name: Ananda Bhavan Restaurant

7.body: Indian Muslim restaurant famous for its Soup Tulang (bone marrow soup).
7.description: Indian Muslim restaurant famous for its Soup Tulang (bone marrow soup).
7.name: M.A Deen Biasa

8.body: Casual dining place with a  menu featuring a variety of delicious Indian dishes.
8.description: Casual dining place with a  menu featuring a variety of delicious Indian dishes.
8.name: Prata Mee

9.body: A heritage South-Indian Muslim restaurant that's famous for its biryani and murtabak.
9.description: A heritage South-Indian Muslim restaurant that's famous for its biryani and murtabak.
9.name: Zam Zam

10.body: Serves delicious North Indian dishes such as chicken tikka, dal makhani, naan and more.
10.description: Serves delicious North Indian dishes such as chicken tikka, dal makhani, naan and more.
10.name: Punjaby Dawat

11.body: Enjoy authentic Pan-Indian cuisine and craft cocktails in a fun and quirky space.
11.description: Enjoy authentic Pan-Indian cuisine and craft cocktails in a fun and quirky space.
11.name: Flying Monkey

12.body: MeatSmith Little India is Singapore’s first restaurant serving Modern Indian Barbecue. With its colorful façade and street artwork, this outlet fits perfectly at its home, at Campbell Lane in the heart of Little India.
12.description: MeatSmith Little India is Singapore’s first restaurant serving Modern Indian Barbecue.
12.name: Meat Smith Little India

13.body:
Uncover this hidden gem in the heart of Little India where it is not just about food. Learn about Indian cuisine and culture with Master Chef Kaesavan (K7), and bask in the warm hospitality of Curry Mummy Kumaarrie and Teacher Shanti.

At this chef-owned restaurant, you are invited to kick off your shoes and make yourself at home. Like home-cooked food, no MSG is used in our cooking. The flavors are brought out with the thoughtful play of spices and cooking techniques. The dishes are made with fresh quality ingredients and ayurvedic philosophy.

Discover your #ChilliLevels and enjoy our food at your preferred spice level. For the adventurous chilli lovers, discover your threshold with our #ChilliChallenge.

Lagnaa is available for dine-in, delivery and takeaway. Place your reservations and orders on http://order.lagnaa.com/ to get flavourful Indian food at your fingertips!
13.description: Discover the 6 flavours of authentic Indian cuisine at this homely MICHELIN Guide Restaurant.
13.name: Lagnaa... barefoot dining

14.body: Housing a wide variety of Malay and Indian food, Geylang Serai Market and Food Centre makes a great stop for hungry travellers. For tasty bites, visit Kueh Talam Asli (#02-148) for an assortment of kueh talam, a two-layered Malaysian dessert, and Otak-Otak Kampung (#02-164) for otah (spicy fish paste grilled in banana leaf). For a hearty meal, tuck into Malay-style chicken rice at Nasi Ayam Sambal (#02-129). Its unique spicy sambal adds a kick to the dish and is highly recommended. To cool down, enjoy smooth and deliciously rich chendol (a dessert with jelly, coconut milk and palm sugar syrup) from Cendol Geylang Serai (#02-107).
14.description: From snacks to filling meals, the food centre offers plenty of Malay and Indian food.
14.name: Geylang Serai Market and Food Centre

15.body:
Gayatri Restaurant started the restaurant Operations in 1996 at Chander Road and two years later relocated at 19 Race Course Lane Off Serangoon Road. The new restaurant branch is currently open at 122 Race Course Road with the aim of providing our customers tasty and delicious food.

Gayatri is known for electic northern and southern Indian cuisine, our restaurant is also noted for its open concept kitchen where inquisitive diners can peek at the chefs flipping naans or grilling thier favourite Tandoori dish behind tempered glass walls. We also provide catering services for private functions including family celebration, weddings, corpo- rate and community events. We are capable or handling up to 5,000 patrons a day, usually on busy weekends or public holidays. We had catered to functions and parties for Bollywood & Kollywood stars from India as well as commu- nity events graced by Singapore ministers, MPs and grassroots leaders.
15.description: At Gayatri, we take that one step further by serving you authentic Indian flavours that will remind you of your mother's cooking and India. Served in a cosy family-friendly setting, our chefs from India bring you traditional Indian food, both North Indian and South Indian, guaranteeing to whet everyone's appe- tite. Being one of the oldest banana leaf establishments in Little India, we endeavour to bring you the best Indian food in Singapore at affordable prices.
15.name: Gayatri Restaurant

16.body: Visitors seeking authentic hawker fare in a more refined setting should head to StraitsKitchen at Grand Hyatt Singapore, Singapore’s first SG Clean Quality Mark hotel. Smart casual dress code applies. This restaurant serves a sumptuous buffet spread of local favourites (lunch: S$62++; dinner: S$72++), including dishes of the Peranakans (Straits-born people of Chinese and Malay/Indonesian heritage), Chinese and Indian cuisine, and popular hawker staples such as satay (grilled meat skewers), laksa (spicy coconut milk-based noodle soup) and chicken rice, all in a chic steel-and-marble dining hall. For dessert, the freshly made nonya kueh (bite-sized snacks or desserts) and homemade ice creams are not to be missed at StraitsKitchen. Child rates available.
16.description: Enjoy a sumptuous buffet spread of local delights ranging from Peranakan to Chinese to Indian dishes at this chic restaurant.
16.name: StraitsKitchen

17.body: A 110-year-old Southern Indian-Muslim restaurant that is famous for its murtabak, a flatbread with meat fillings.
17.description: A 110-year-old Southern Indian-Muslim restaurant that is famous for its murtabak, a flatbread with meat fillings.
17.name: Victory Restaurant

18.body:
Vegetarian-friendly, Vegan-friendly, Jain-friendly

Café Salivation is the first Western vegetarian café in Little India and offers vegan-friendly fare with subtle Indian influences. Aromatic spices are used to create flavourful, well-balanced dishes such as the grilled Desi Sandwich with green chutney and a mix of grilled potatoes, tomatoes and cucumbers. The café can omit onion and garlic upon request. For sweets, there are the vegan options such as the Coconut Rose Pannacotta (S$6.50++). A weekday teatime set with a choice of cake and coffee is available throughout the day.
18.description: The first Western vegetarian restaurant in Little India, Café Salivation offers vegan-friendly fare with Indian influences.
18.name: Café Salivation

19.body: This family-owned business opened more than 50 years ago in a corner of Dempsey Road and continues to draw diners to that very same location today. The Indian restaurant, simply decorated and mostly ventilated by ceiling fans, seats up to 300 guests and serves dishes on fresh banana leaves. Diners can choose from dishes like briyani (an Indian spiced rice dish with meat or vegetables), fried cauliflower, Mysore mutton and masala (a marinade of mixed Indian spices) chicken; or order their bestsellers such as the fish cutlet and curry fish head–fresh red snapper fish head stewed in a curry with assorted vegetables.
19.description: This dining establishment has been serving up plates iconic Indian dishes like fish  head curry, for over 50 years.
19.name: Samy's Curry
